name: Kepler-171
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-171 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-171 is a star with 0.7350000000000001 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.84 times its radius. It is located 2887.88 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-171 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-171 b

Kepler-171 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 4.17 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-171.

The mass of Kepler-171 b is 7.42 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-171 b is 2.34 that of Earth. At 7.42 Earth masses, Kepler-171 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-171 c

Kepler-171 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.10 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 11.46 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-171.

The mass of Kepler-171 c is 9.15 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-171 c is 2.56 that of Earth. At 9.15 Earth masses, Kepler-171 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-171 d

Kepler-171 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.22 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 39.60 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-171.

The mass of Kepler-171 d is 4.46 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-171 d is 1.89 that of Earth. At 4.46 Earth masses, Kepler-171 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-171, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
